case_name: State of Tamil Nadu v. Abdul Karim

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1366, 1850 to 1863, 2550 to 2551 of 1969, 1355, 1356 of 1970, and 1292 and 1293 of 1973 were filed in the Supreme Court.
The appeals are from judgments and orders dated 1st March/26th February 1969/29th July/2nd August 1971 of the Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgments Order dated the 1st March/26th February 1969/29th July/2nd August, 1971 of the Madras High Court in W.Ps. Nos. 1895 of 1966, 1084, 1192, 1194, 1800, 1896, 1898, 1907-1910, 2089 of 1966, 646 of 1967, 3536-3537 of 1965 and Tax Cases Nos. 57 58 of 1969 and 191 197 of 1971 respectively.

facts.text: Madras High Court delivered judgments in W.Ps. Nos. 1895 of 1966, 1084, 1192, 1194, 1800, 1896, 1898, 1907-1910, 2089 of 1966, 646 of 1967, 3536-3537 of 1965 and Tax Cases Nos. 57, 58 of 1969 and 191-197 of 1971.
The judgment of the Supreme Court was delivered by ALGIRSWAMI, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALGIRSWAMI, J.-These appeals raise the question of the validity of section 2 1  of Madras Act 37 of 1964.

facts.text: Rule 16 of the Madras General Sales Tax Rules made under Madras Act IX of 1939 was struck down by the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This Rule was struck down by this Court on the ground that where a tanner buys raw hides and skins inside the State and sells them after tanning he pays the tax only on the purchase price of raw hides and whereas a dealer who purchases raw hides and skins from outside the State and sells the tanned hides and skins pays the tax on the price for which tanned hides and skins are sold and therefore pays more tax.

facts.text: The Supreme Court struck down Rule 16 in Firm A.T.B. Mehtab Majid Co. v. State of Madras reported in 1963 Supp. S.C.R. 435.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of this Court in Firm A.T.B. Mehtab Majid Co. v. State of Madras is reported in 1963 Supp. S.C.R. 435. Thereafter the Madras Legislature passed Act 11 of 1963 to deal with this situation.

facts.text: Madras Legislature passed Act 11 of 1963 after the striking down of Rule 16.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Madras Legislature passed Act 11 of 1963 to deal with this situation. Section 2 1  of that Act reads as follows,

facts.text: Section 2(1) of Madras Act 11 of 1963 was struck down by the Supreme Court in A. Hajee Abdul Shakoor Co. v. State of Madras 1964 8 S.C.R. 217.

anchor.surface_text: it was struck down by this Court in A. Hajee Abdul Shakoor Co. v. State of Madras 1964 8 S.C.R. 217  on the ground that for the period from 1st April, 1955 to 31st March, 1957 there was a discrimination

facts.text: From 1st April 1955 to 31st March 1957 the rate of taxation in Madras State was one and nine-sixteenth per cent.

anchor.surface_text: From 1st April 1955 to 31st March 1957 the rate of taxation in Madras State, was one and nine-sixteenth per cent. As the section provided a uniform rate of two per cent for sales during the whole of the period between ist April 1955 and 31st March 1959

facts.text: Madras Act 37 of 1964 was passed to address the objection from the Hajee Abdul Shakoor case.

anchor.surface_text: It is to get over this objection that the section first referred to has been passed. Under the section the tax is leviable on the first seller of dressed hides and skins at the rate of one and nine- sixteenth per cent for the period between 1st April 1955 and 31st March 1957.

facts.text: The Madras High Court struck down section 2(1) of Madras Act 37 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the High Court was in error in striking down the impugned provision of law.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that section 2(1) of Madras Act 37 of 1964 is valid.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the High Court was in error in striking down the impugned provision of law. In S.L.P. No.

facts.text: Govind Swaminathan, Advocate General for the State of Tamil Nadu appeared for the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Govind Swaminathan, Advocate General for the State of Tamil Nadu, A. V. Rangam, K. Venkataswami, N.S. Sivam and A. Subhashini, for the appellants  In all the Appeals SLP No. 1974/70  Abdul Karim and K. Rajendra Choudhary, for the respondents

facts.text: The tax under section 2(1) of Madras Act 37 of 1964 applies for period commencing 1st April 1955 ending 31st March 1957 at one nine-sixteenth per cent.

anchor.surface_text: Special provisions in respect of tax on sale of dressed hides and skins in certain cases - Notwithstanding anything companytained in the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939  Madras Act IX of 1939   hereinafter referred to as the said Act , or in the rules made thereunder  hereinafter referred to as the said Rules , in respect of sale of dressed hides and skins  which were number subjected to tax under the said Act as raw hides skins , the tax under the said Act shall be levied from the dealer who in the State is the first seller in such hides and skins number exempt from taxation under sub-sec.  3  of Sec. 3 of the said Act- for the period companymencing on the 1st April 1955 and ending on the 31st March 1957, at the rate of one nine- sixteenth per cent,

facts.text: The tax rate under the impugned section for period 1st April 1957 to 31st March 1959 is two per cent.

anchor.surface_text: and for the period companymencing on the 1st April-, 1957 and ending on the 31st March 1959, at the rate of two per cent, of the amount for which such hides and skins were last purchased in the- untanned companydition.

facts.text: Rule 16 provided that in case of untanned hides and skins, tax is levied from the last purchaser in the State not exempt under Sec. 3(3).

anchor.surface_text: Rule 16 of the Madras General Sales Tax, Rules made under Madras Act IX of 1939 read as follows In the case of untanned hides and or skins the tax under Sec. 3 1  shall be levied from the dealer who is the last purchaser in the State number exempt from taxation under Sec. 3 3  en the amount for which they are bought by him.
section 2 1  of Madras Act 37 of 1964. That section reads as follows Special provisions in respect of tax on sale of dressed hides and skins in certain cases

concepts.interpretation: Levy of sales tax on first intra-state seller of dressed hides and skins not previously taxed as raw, at historical rates for 1955-1957 (1 and 9/16%) and 1957-1959 (2%), computed on last purchase price of untanned hides/skins regardless of intra or inter-state origin; held valid, no discrimination or Art. 286 violation.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1366, 1850 to 1863, 2550 to 2551 of 1969, 1355, 1356 of 1970, and 1292 and 1293 of 1973 were filed in the Supreme Court.

issues.text: Whether section 2(1) of Madras Act 37 of 1964 is valid?

anchor.surface_text: These appeals raise the question of the validity of section 2 1  of Madras Act 37 of 1964. That section reads as follows Special provisions in respect of tax on sale of dressed hides and skins in certain cases

issues.text: Whether the tax under section 2(1) of Madras Act 37 of 1964 discriminates between sellers of tanned hides and skins based on whether raw hides and skins were purchased inside or outside the State?

anchor.surface_text: Thus there is numberdiscrimination between the sellers of tanned hides and skins whether the raw hide and skins out of which they were tanned were purchased inside the State or outside the State. The tax itself is on the first sale of the tanned hides and skins but it is calculated on the basis of the purchase per price of the raw hides and skins whether they word purchased inside the State or outside the State.

issues.text: Whether the tax levied on the sale of tanned hides and skins under section 2(1) of Madras Act 37 of 1964 contravenes Article 286 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: We do number, therefore, sea how the tax levied on the sale of tanned hides and skins companytravenes Articles 286 of the Constitution. Actually as the value of hides and skins in their tanned companydition is higher than the value of raw hides and skins from out of which they are tanned the person importing raw hides and skins from outside the State can have numbergrievance that the tax is levied number on the amount for which the tanned hides and skins are sold but on the amount for which raw hides and skins have been purchased.

arguments.claim: There is no discrimination between the sellers of tanned hides and skins whether the raw hides and skins out of which they were tanned were purchased inside the State or outside the State.

anchor.surface_text: Thus there is numberdiscrimination between the sellers of tanned hides and skins whether the raw hide and skins out of which they were tanned were purchased inside the State or outside the State. The tax itself is on the first sale of the tanned hides and skins but it is calculated on the basis of the purchase per price of the raw hides and skins whether they word purchased inside the State or outside the State.

arguments.claim: The tax levied on the sale of tanned hides and skins does not contravene Article 286 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We do number, therefore, sea how the tax levied on the sale of tanned hides and skins companytravenes Articles 286 of the Constitution. Actually as the value of hides and skins in their tanned companydition is higher than the value of raw hides and skins from out of which they are tanned the person importing raw hides and skins from outside the State can have numbergrievance that the tax is levied number on the amount for which the tanned hides and skins are sold but on the amount for which raw hides and skins have been purchased.

arguments.claim: If the sale price of tanned hides and skins were taxed with a rebate given, there would be no objection to the tax.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to understand the view of the High Court that if the sale price were taxed and rebate were given then there would be numberobjection to the tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ppearing for the respondents to tell us how that can be done and they were number able to do so. The companyt of companyversion of the raw hides and s

arguments.court_reasoning: Unclear how rebate for cost of conversion can be implemented as costs vary by tanner and are hard to verify; easier to use purchase or sale price figures; respondents unable to explain; does not fit taxation scheme.

arguments.claim: Section 2(1) of Madras Act 37 of 1964 is valid; High Court erred in striking it down.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the High Court was in error in striking down the impugned provision of law.

arguments.claim: The impugned section addresses the discrimination objection from A. Hajee Abdul Shakoor by applying period-specific historical tax rates.

anchor.surface_text: It is to get over this objection that the section first referred to has been passed. Under the section the tax is leviable on the first seller of dressed hides and skins at the rate of one and nine- sixteenth per cent for the period between 1st April 1955 and 31st March 1957.

arguments.claim: Using raw purchase price for tax quantification is administratively easier than sale price minus conversion cost.

anchor.surface_text: The companyt of companyversion of the raw hides and skins to tanned hides and skins might differ from tanner to tanner. It is much easier to get figures. for the purchase price of the raw hides and skins or the sale price of the tanned hides and skins than the companyt of companyversion.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in striking down the impugned provision of law.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the High Court was in error in striking down the impugned provision of law. In S.L.P. No.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section applies correct historical rates for each period, eliminates discrimination by taxing first intra-state sale of tanned hides/skins on uniform raw purchase price basis regardless of origin, does not tax inter-state purchases directly, distinguishes prior invalidations.

holdings.text: there is no discrimination between the sellers of tanned hides and skins whether the raw hides and skins out of which they were tanned were purchased inside the State or outside the State.

anchor.surface_text: Thus there is no discrimination between the sellers of tanned hides and skins whether the raw hide and skins out of which they were tanned were purchased inside the State or outside the State. The tax itself is on the first sale of the tanned hides and skins but it is calculated on the basis of the purchase price of the raw hides and skins whether they were purchased inside the State or outside the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax levied on first intra-state sale of tanned product for both intra-state and imported raw hides/skins, quantified uniformly on last purchase price of raw untanned hides/skins.

holdings.text: We do not, therefore, see how the tax levied on the sale of tanned hides and skins contravenes Article 286 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, therefore, see how the tax levied on the sale of tanned hides and skins contravenes Article 286 of the Constitution. Actually as the value of hides and skins in their tanned condition is higher than the value of raw hides and skins from out of which they are tanned the person importing raw hides and skins from outside the State can have no grievance that the tax is levied not on the amount for which the tanned hides and skins are sold but on the amount for which raw hides and skins have been purchased.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax is on intra-state first sale of tanned hides/skins (not inter-state raw import), quantified on lower raw purchase price rather than higher tanned sale price; inter-state raw purchases taxable under Central Sales Tax Act instead.

holdings.text: the suggestion of the High Court [that taxing sale price with rebate for conversion cost would be unobjectionable] cannot be adopted.

anchor.surface_text: As the scheme of taxation is not on the basis of the sale price of tanned hides and skins the suggestion of the High Court cannot be adopted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conversion costs vary by tanner and are difficult to verify/administer; easier to use verifiable purchase or sale price figures; respondents unable to explain implementation.
